content: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software DevelopersThe software engineering market didn’t die. It just moved on without telling you. We’re in a new era. The bootcamp-to-job pipeline is dried up. Certificates are noise. AI tossed a grenade into the hiring funnel. There are more software jobs open now than there were two years ago AND it’s more difficult to get hired. It feels like the rules are completely different because they are.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: rules are completely different because they are. Here’s some advice that’s too harsh for LinkedIn but I think you’ll find useful if you’re a newer developer on the market. 1. Vibe coding is not a career or a replacement for actual skillCopy/pasting from ChatGPT and “figuring it out later” isn’t a real workflow. Build less like a hacker, more like an engineer. You should understand your tools, the stack, and what happens after you click “deploy.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: stack, and what happens after you click “deploy. ”Vibe coders are running up cloud credits by exposing private information or scrambling to hire back software developers the moment their app grows beyond simple use cases or a few dozen files. I give it another year and “vibe coders” will be regarded with the same reverence as “prompt engineers. ”Remember when that was a thing. 2. No one cares about your certificate. Your Coursera badge. That AI Fundamentals YouTube playlist.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: badge. That AI Fundamentals YouTube playlist. The completion certificate from Parsity. io. (btw — I run this program and still don’t advise mentees to share this… just saying)Hiring managers aren’t impressed and it can actually be a red flag, unless you’re in DevOps or some role that requires AWS/GCP certifications. For any full stack role, these certs are more noise than signal. Certs don’t necessarily hurt but they rarely help. 4. If you must build a portfolio, don’t do it from scratch.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: must build a portfolio, don’t do it from scratch. Use Vercel’s V0 or another AI site builder. This weekend, I vibe-coded an entire site that looks better than anything I could’ve done on my own. Check it out. Should that scare me. I don’t know. I do know that building fancy landing pages is not a job I want to do. AI tools will almost certainly make something better than your hand-coded portfolio that breaks as soon as I put it in mobile view.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: that breaks as soon as I put it in mobile view. Let’s be honest: when digging through a stack of resumes, no one is going to look at your links. Following random links is a big no-no at most orgs and managers simply don’t have time. Yes — I’ve met more than a few devs who got hired because of their portfolio. In 2013. 5. Full-stack is the new baseline. “Front-end only” roles are fading. Stack Overflow’s yearly survey reported only 10% of professional developers identify as front-end.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: of professional developers identify as front-end. I was shocked and a little sad to see this but it tracks with my experience. Modern teams expect you to be able to touch the backend, databases, and maybe even cloud infra. You don’t need to be an expert in all these areas. You just need to be fluent enough to be deployed to these areas. Start with Node + Express and here’s a free starter kit to get going:👉 https://github. com/CodeCoachJS/node_express_starter6.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: com/CodeCoachJS/node_express_starter6. AI productivity is a lie — but you still have to play the game. There’s a sickening trend of devs claiming they’re “10x more productive” because of AI. Companies want to believe this. Their shareholders are betting on it. What could go wrong. Google found out that AI improved developer productivity by 10%. Not 10x. 10%. But why ruin the fun with facts and numbers. So what do you do.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the fun with facts and numbers. So what do you do. Become “AI-first” — I hate myself a little for even typing that…On the shallow end:Use Cursor or Claude or whateverMention it on your resumeAuto-complete better and fasterExperiment with agents and different models/tools for software developmentManagers are scrambling to hire AI-enabled developers to appease their bosses who told their investors they would become 100x more productive this year by becoming “AI-native” — whatever the fuck that means.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: “AI-native” — whatever the fuck that means. Now, if you actually want to develop the hard skills related to LLMs. Learn RAGRead up on transformers, attention mechanisms and paged attentionUse vector databasesBuild agentic workflowsThese are the skills that will actually make you valuable and I cover all of it in the upcoming Parsity AI Developer Course for people who want to build real, modern, AI-powered software. 7. Learning four languages makes you look unfocused. Pick one stack and go deep.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: you look unfocused. Pick one stack and go deep. JavaScript + TypeScript is enough. Listing Rust, Go, Python, and Java after six months. 🚩While I’m at it: remove those proficiency levels under the languages you list. No one knows what 65% at TypeScript means and it scares recruiters. 8. You’ll never feel “ready. ”There’s no magical “I’m ready now” moment. Apply before you’re ready. If you meet 50% of the requirements for a role then you need to apply.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: requirements for a role then you need to apply. If you meet 100% of the requirements then you’re over-qualified. Don’t down-level yourself. The titles junior/mid-level/senior mean completely different things at different organizations. Let the interview dictate your ability to do the job. Stop filtering yourself out before anyone else does. 9. Hiring is broken but your network isn’t. Yes, I know some people are still mass applying and getting interviews.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: are still mass applying and getting interviews. But at Parsity, the people who land jobs are doing something else:They’re using their real-world network and it works. They’re former teachers, chefs, EMTs. They find their first job by reaching out to former colleagues, old classmates, friends-of-friends, or local businesses. It’s rarely someone you know directly that can help you with that first role. It’s almost always a friend of friend of a friend. Be methodical and do a BFS of your network.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Be methodical and do a BFS of your network. If you don’t get that reference… look it up. Bottom lineThis market isn’t hopeless. It’s different. It rewards deep skills, real projects, product thinking, and practical AI fluency (or at least the illusion of it 😅). My super opinionated advice:If you’re an early career developer and lacking in technical skills: consider a strategic investment in up-skilling with AI by building out a full stack web app using agents or RAG.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: out a full stack web app using agents or RAG. If you are having zero luck in the job market — consider doing an audit of your network to “shake the tree” and find some people who might be able to point you to someone you can talk to. As usual, I hope that’s helpful and not too harsh.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Building Your First AI AgentI want you to break what I builtLast year I joined an AI start-up and started building my first agent for a large project we were working on. It was exciting and messy. No one on the engineering team had any expertise with AI or working with LLMs. This “agent” was supposed to take a prompt, determine if we could actually handle the request and then do a search of either a vector database or do a web search.

metadata.title: Building Your First AI Agent
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: of either a vector database or do a web search. It might return some text or an array of objects depending on the outcome. It was bloated, inefficient and costly. I had no clue what I was doing. This massive agent was breaking one of the cardinal rules of building software: SRP. Single Responsibility Principle. Our CEO was an AI OG, luckily, and had some experience with agents before they became cool.

metadata.title: Building Your First AI Agent
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: experience with agents before they became cool. He helped us re-think our logic and then we broke up our “agent” in to multiple, self-contained agents that were each responsible for 1 thing. 1 agent to summarize the conversation. 1 orchestrator to decide which agent to call next. 1 agent for a vector search. 1 agent for a web search. Clean. Simple. Cost-effective. Composable.

metadata.title: Building Your First AI Agent
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: search. Clean. Simple. Cost-effective. Composable. While everyone is having an existential crisis about the future of tech — there is a massive re-shuffling happening under our feet. This means massive opportunity. The more I work with AI, the more bullish I am about the future of tech and software engineering specifically.

metadata.title: Building Your First AI Agent
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: of tech and software engineering specifically. Most of the same skills that were important before AI will be important going forward: debugging, system design, clean code and solving tough problems with code aren’t going anywhere. Owning a camera doesn’t make you a photographer, much in the same way that writing some code with AI does not make you a software developer. While the “old” skills are still relevant, the tech we use is undergoing a massive overhaul.

metadata.title: Building Your First AI Agent
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the tech we use is undergoing a massive overhaul. Learning how to build agents, work with vector databases and monitor these agents are emerging skills that most developers just haven’t had experience with yet. This shift is why I’m building something for Parsity students to make sure they have exposure to this new tech stack. You can check it out at Parsity. aiBecause I like you, I built a very small project to introduce you to agents using Gemini and plain HTML and JS.

metadata.title: Building Your First AI Agent
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: you to agents using Gemini and plain HTML and JS. This project uses 2 agents to estimate how many calories you consumed based on what you ate in the day. One agent determines if we have enough information to provide an estimate of your calories and the other agent returns the estimate. Simple and maybe even useful. You won’t get much out of just reading about it though. The ONLY way to learn is to get your hands dirty.

metadata.title: Building Your First AI Agent
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: The ONLY way to learn is to get your hands dirty. Step 1: Get a free key from Google to use their Gemini model: https://aistudio. google. com/apikeyStep 2: Visit https://codepen. io/Brian-Jenney/pen/PwqLQLW. editors=1010 and start getting your hands dirty with the Diet Tracker App. Step 3: Break, re-write and extend the project. Change the output format. Can you add another agent. The only way to actually learn is to get your hands dirty.

metadata.title: Building Your First AI Agent
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: way to actually learn is to get your hands dirty. If the code is out of your depth then you should consider our Dev30 program to help you learn the basics of JS. Enjoy. I write emails to early career developers hereI talk to early career developers here: Develop Yourself.

metadata.title: Building Your First AI Agent
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Tom, pitcured above, is a 35 year old senior software developerIf You’re Over 30 and Trying to Learn to Code, Read This First. When’s the last time you really learned something. Not a quick YouTube tutorial. Not a how-to guide. I’m talking about deep, uncomfortable, make-you-question-how-smart-you-are type of learning. The kind that rewires your brain. For most people, it hasn’t happened since school and that’s part of the problem.

metadata.title: If You’re Over 30 and Trying to Learn to Code, Read This First.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: since school and that’s part of the problem. There’s a reason the traditional path to software engineering involves school. Structured learning, homework and feedback loops train your brain to endure confusion, repetition, boredom, and struggle. But when you’re over 30, trying to switch careers with a job, a family, and limited time… that structure is gone. You’ve probably developed some skills and are pretty good at a few things.

metadata.title: If You’re Over 30 and Trying to Learn to Code, Read This First.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: some skills and are pretty good at a few things. You’re not used to sucking at something new so your tolerance for it is low. 15 Years Ago, My Life Was UnrecognizableI wasn’t sitting behind a laptop writing JavaScript. I was addicted to drugs, drinking heavily, and paying rent through illegal means. Coding wasn’t on my radar. A W-2 wasn’t on my radar. Fast forward seven years: I was flying first class to New York to give a talk in front of a room full of Fortune 500 executives. No CS degree.

metadata.title: If You’re Over 30 and Trying to Learn to Code, Read This First.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: room full of Fortune 500 executives. No CS degree. No Ivy League resume. Just years of self-learning, some luck, and a lot of building. I don’t know many fields that let you completely reinvent your life. Tech does. But don’t confuse that opportunity with ease. This was not easy. And it’s definitely not a get-rich-quick scheme. People join a coding bootcamp, memorize a few things, and expect job offers to rain from the sky in 90 days. When they don’t, they scream “Scam.

metadata.title: If You’re Over 30 and Trying to Learn to Code, Read This First.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: in 90 days. When they don’t, they scream “Scam. ”Let me tell you what the real scam is: thinking you can memorize information and get paid six figures for it. This is not a memorization job. It’s a thinking job. A curious person’s job. And more than anything, it’s a job that rewards the people who learn how to learn. If you’re over 30, thinking of breaking into tech, here are 4 mindset shifts you’re going to need to make to have a shot at success. 1.

metadata.title: If You’re Over 30 and Trying to Learn to Code, Read This First.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: to need to make to have a shot at success. 1. Learn How to Learn (Seriously)You’re not in school anymore. No one is chasing you. You have to own your learning process or you will get eaten alive.

metadata.title: If You’re Over 30 and Trying to Learn to Code, Read This First.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: your learning process or you will get eaten alive. You need to:Filter resources instead of binging every tutorialActually read the documentationAsk better questions, especially when stuckPractice spaced repetition and revisit concepts over timeWrite down what you don’t understand, not just what you doIf you want a method, here’s a good one:The Feynman TechniquePick a topic (e. g.

metadata.title: If You’re Over 30 and Trying to Learn to Code, Read This First.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: good one:The Feynman TechniquePick a topic (e. g. closures, promises, the call stack)Try to explain it in simple termsIdentify what you can’t explainGo back, learn it again, then re-explain itThat’s the core of how people at Parsity get good. But we take it one step further:2. Learn by Teaching (on Camera)The most uncomfortable (and most effective) way to learn. Teach. At Parsity, we have students do something that makes 99% of people squirm:Learn a concept, then record themselves teaching it.

metadata.title: If You’re Over 30 and Trying to Learn to Code, Read This First.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: a concept, then record themselves teaching it. No ChatGPT. No script. Just freestyle, off the dome. Teach what a closure is. Explain how a debugger works. Walk through asynchronous JavaScript to a non-technical audience. Then go back and watch yourself. Cringe if you must. Then do it again. And again. Do this 100 times, and I guarantee the fear disappears. The only reason people fear speaking or teaching is because it’s novel. Do it enough, and it becomes boring — like anything else.

metadata.title: If You’re Over 30 and Trying to Learn to Code, Read This First.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: and it becomes boring — like anything else. I say this as someone who used to hate speaking in meetings. Now. I’ve made close to a thousand videos. The nerves go away. The clarity improves. And your understanding becomes stronger. If you can teach it, you know it. 3. Develop Curiosity or Don’t BotherCuriosity isn’t optional, it’s a silent requirement for this job. You have to be the kind of person who wonders: How does that work. Why does that break. What happens if I change this.

metadata.title: If You’re Over 30 and Trying to Learn to Code, Read This First.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: does that break. What happens if I change this. This isn’t a checklist-following job. It’s a tinkerer’s job. You’re an engineer in the same way a mechanic is: breaking things, rebuilding them, and understanding how they tick. If you’re not curious about what’s happening under the hood, it’s going to be a grind. But if you lean into it, coding becomes less like homework and more like solving puzzles for a living. 4. Build It. Break It. Rebuild It. Stop trying to memorize everything. Clone apps.

metadata.title: If You’re Over 30 and Trying to Learn to Code, Read This First.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Stop trying to memorize everything. Clone apps. Break them. Rebuild them. Forget the people who say clone projects are worthless they’re wrong. I hate to say I’m guilty of this 😬. Check out John Crickett’s Coding Challenges for some examples of complex software to replicate. Every time you rebuild something from scratch, you internalize the architecture. You recognize patterns. You finally get why something works not just that it does. Imitation is the beginning of mastery.

metadata.title: If You’re Over 30 and Trying to Learn to Code, Read This First.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: it does. Imitation is the beginning of mastery. Final ThoughtIf you’re over 30, switching careers, and trying to learn to code, you’re not too late. But you are on a different path. You’re bringing more baggage, more responsibility, more real-world experience and less free time. That’s not a disadvantage. It’s your edge IF you develop the mindset. Learn how to learn. Teach to understand. Stay curious. Build more. I run an anti-coding-bootcamp where you won’t touch code for the first 8 weeks.

metadata.title: If You’re Over 30 and Trying to Learn to Code, Read This First.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: where you won’t touch code for the first 8 weeks. Crazy, like a fox. Learn more here.

metadata.title: If You’re Over 30 and Trying to Learn to Code, Read This First.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: They’re Lying to You About AI ProductivityTech CEOs over-promising and under-delivering. Balderdash. You’re just coping. Am I. <Begin Rant>I’ve been pretty vocal about the over-hype of AI coding tools and I always get the same responses from AI bros:“YoU gOtta PrOmpt bEtteR. ”“This iz a skillz issue dawg”“I’m using [x] and it works perfectly”“I’m a super duper senior architect and I’ve replaced my entire team with AI agents. You’re coping. ”I’d be lying if I said I didn’t doubt myself.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: ”I’d be lying if I said I didn’t doubt myself. Maybe they’re right, maybe I’m just not using these tools correctly. But, now I’m convinced. They’re either liars, naive or truly top. 01% coders with whom mortals cannot compete. Every other day I read about some developer who is 10x’ing their output with AI tools. Companies like Salesforce and Microsoft are claiming that AI is making them SOOOOOO productive they just have to fire their developers. So what gives.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: just have to fire their developers. So what gives. Let’s take a look at some big fax and small fax to understand where the truth ends and the hype begins. It’s been 6 months — why are there more developer jobs. Remember when the Lizard King told Joe Rogan that AI would be replacing mid-level engineers in 6 months. That was 6 months ago. Do you remember when Devin was supposed to replace ALL software engineers nearly a year ago. And yet — here we are.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: nearly a year ago. And yet — here we are. Despite all these catastrophic events, there are somehow MORE jobs for software developers in June of 2025 than in June of 2024. (source: https://www. trueup. io/job-trend)It’s almost as if these CEOs are pulling predictions straight out of their… hats. Yeah, that’s what I was going to say. Salesforce boasted that they were cutting around 1,000 jobs this year because of AI.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: cutting around 1,000 jobs this year because of AI. BUT they’re also hiring for “AI-aligned” roles like sales engineers — basically just shifting their headcount. Which leads me to the worst and most pervasive lie about AI:1 Senior Developer === 10 Junior DevelopersI call bullsh*t. Ask any developer who’s working on something moderately complex that includes multiple services or a backend system that is more than 3 months old how much [insert tool here] has helped them with their workflow.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: tool here] has helped them with their workflow. It’s like we’re all afraid to admit the truth. Which is… “it depends. ”Truly. Meanwhile, the geniuses on LinkedIn will tell you that they’ve effectively replaced their entire team or at least that they COULD. Ya know, if they wanted. That’s how f*cking effective these tools are. They have an MCP server, a rules file that includes every conceivable scenario their agent may encounter and they write prompts like a cold, dead, robotic Shakespeare.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: prompts like a cold, dead, robotic Shakespeare. Or Tyler Perry. If you’re not seeing the productivity gains, then you’re just using it wrong. Bro. Google did a little study on AI and it’s impact on productivity. 10%. That’s how much more effective their engineers are with AI (source: https://www. businessinsider. com/ai-google-engineers-coding-productive-sundar-pichai-alphabet-2025-6). Outside of tech these gains are more… modest.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Outside of tech these gains are more… modest. One study found office workers unlocked a whopping 3% more productivity (source: https://www. computerworld. com/article/3998244/ai-chatbots-see-fast-adoption-but-deliver-minimal-productivity-gains-study-finds. html). But why ruin the fun with facts and numbers from independent researchers and massive tech companies who meticulously track these kinds of stats. That wouldn’t make for very fun YouTube videos. ROI (Really. Over.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: for very fun YouTube videos. ROI (Really. Over. Indexed)Investors aren’t gonna like this one. Companies weren’t happy enough with the magical powers we’ve gained from having AI tools like Cursor, Co-Pilot and ChatGPT. They wanted earth-shattering, society-crippling change. Auto-complete on steroids just doesn’t have the same ring as AGI. So they wrote slide decks promising the world to investors who have been burned by poor planning, high interest rates and bets on web3, blockchain and crypto.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: rates and bets on web3, blockchain and crypto. How are your NFTs btw. Good. Great. IBM did a survey of thousands of execs and found that only a quarter of AI initiatives have achieved their expected return on investment (ROI) so far, and only 16% have successfully scaled AI across the enterprise (source: https://www. techrepublic. com/article/news-ibm-study-ai-roi/). To many people, this would be considered a failure. But when it comes to AI — you just gotta wait.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: But when it comes to AI — you just gotta wait. Another 6 months and we’ll see those bets paying off. For real this time. [reminder to update this article in 6 months and either laugh or cry or both]<End Rant>For every study I’ve referenced here, there is some other study that will probably show the opposite. Those studies are almost exclusively written by people who have a lot to gain from AI hype. In all honesty, I have a lot to gain as well.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: In all honesty, I have a lot to gain as well. I’m a software engineer and a business owner with a business that mentors early-career coders (Parsity. io btw — check out). How much can you really trust anything I say. I have a novel idea. Use the tools for yourself on non-trivial projects with teams of more than 3 people in codebases that aren’t exclusively front end. Draw your own conclusions. Read studies. Look at reality. Do you personally know a single person who has been replaced by AI.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: know a single person who has been replaced by AI. Do you know anyone who’s bought a slice of pizza with crypto. All is not bad though. Personally, this is the most fun I’ve had coding so far in my career. The reality is that I AM more productive. I don’t HAVE to write nearly as much code and I can build a sexy-ass (simple) web app in minutes instead of days. I love the tools. I hate the hype. Anyways — enjoy this blooper reel to end the show. That’s all folks.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary. Five years ago, during an interview for a senior dev role, I had a panic attack. My heart was pounding. I couldn’t get my words out. I had to ask the interviewer to restart the call. I was embarrassed, shaky, and 100% sure I’d blown it. Plot twist: I got the job, but it was one of many interview disasters I’ve had over the years. And it showed me just how broken my approach was.

metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: And it showed me just how broken my approach was. Here’s the thing: I was already decent at writing code. I wasn’t struggling to do the job. I was struggling to get the job. That’s a really frustrating place to be. In one interview at the beginning of my career, a guy asked me about JavaScript object referential equality. I fumbled hard. He ended up explaining it to me during the call, like I was a student — not a candidate.

metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the call, like I was a student — not a candidate. Another time I bombed a Facebook interview so badly that I just cut it short. I couldn’t solve a recursion problem and I knew I was just wasting time so I pulled the plug and bailed early. I left these interviews thinking:Maybe I’m just not cut out for this. But I’m stubborn. And obsessed with patterns. So I started breaking the whole process down and rebuilding it from the ground up. Here’s what changed everything:1.

metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the ground up. Here’s what changed everything:1. I Built a Library of Personal StoriesI’ve done somewhere around 100 interviews in the last 11 years as an engineering manager and software engineer. I’ve noticed that most interviews have the same 4–5 behavioral questions, just reworded:Tell me about a time you solved a hard technical problemTell me about a time you had a conflict with a teammateWhat’s a project you’re proud of. When did you fail.

metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: a project you’re proud of. When did you fail. So I started cataloging real stories from my work that mapped to those questions. I’d jot them down in a doc, grouped by theme. I knew the stories cold — what happened, what I learned, and what they revealed about me. As an engineering manager, I asked these same questions and what I realized I was really trying to understand was:“Can I imagine this person working here. ”Once I understood that, I shaped my own stories to “sell” myself.

metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: that, I shaped my own stories to “sell” myself. What good is passing the coding round in an interview just to bomb the behavioral sections. These questions will often make up the majority of your interview rounds and yet they get the least attention online. Here’s an exercise for you to help organize a technical story for your next interview: Link to the document2. I Got Clear on the Technical GapsI didn’t try to become a master of everything.

metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: GapsI didn’t try to become a master of everything. I focused on the concepts that tripped me up repeatedly: closures, prototype inheritance, recursion and coding challenges. I built small projects in vanilla JavaScript. I made videos explaining these concepts out loud. I wrote code until I didn’t need to look things up anymore. Eventually, I compiled all of it into a repo I now share with the devs I mentor and it often kicks their ass. 3. I Trained Myself to Be CalmThis was the hardest part.

metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Myself to Be CalmThis was the hardest part. I’m naturally a nervous, high-energy person. So I did something weird: I sought out interviews I knew I’d fail. Just to get used to the feeling. I used Pramp. I interviewed with strangers. I bombed questions. I embarrassed myself. But I got used to it. This was not fun. This was super effective. After a while, interviews started to feel routine. Like skydiving (at least, I imaging): terrifying the first time, boring after 100 jumps.

metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: terrifying the first time, boring after 100 jumps. I wanted interviews to be boring. And eventually… they were. The Result. My salary went from $60K to a peak of $290K, with a $200K base. Obviously, the salary bumps changed my life, but more importantly, I’m a lot less worried about IF I can land another role. Learning to interview is the single most high leverage skill you can have as a software developer. Is it fair. NoIs it reality. F*ck yes it is.

metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Is it fair. NoIs it reality. F*ck yes it is. And now, I help other developers do the same, in addition to running Parsity. io — an anti-coding-bootcamp for career changers. Want to finally get interviews into a chokehold. If you’re a developer with 1–5 years of experience, and you’re tired of being stuck at the same salary or bombing interviews you know you should’ve crushed — I have something for you. I do NOT do FAANG prep. Go to NeetCode, Interview.

metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: I do NOT do FAANG prep. Go to NeetCode, Interview. io, AlgoExpert or Interview KickStart for that. All great programs and I can personally vouch for AlgoExpert and Interview KickStart. Not sponsored in any sort of way — but I probably should be. I only take 5 people at a max at any given time. If you’re in the US, there’s a damn good chance this unlocks $10K–$50K+ in your next move. 👉 Fill out this short form to apply.

metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: next move. 👉 Fill out this short form to apply. If your interviews are stressful and chaotic right now, I get it — I’ve been there. Let’s make them boring.
