content: A Practical Guide on Building AI AgentsWhat You’ll LearnBy the end of this guide, you’ll understand:What an AI agent is in practical terms. Why they matter for developers today. How to design a small, working agent workflow in TypeScript + Next. js. Lessons I learned building production agents — where people go wrong and how to avoid it. How to add observability and testing so your agents don’t silently break. This isn’t theory.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: agents don’t silently break. This isn’t theory. It’s the guide I wish I had read before I started trying to make agents. The ProblemAt work, I was asked to lead a project for major record labels to find influencers to promote music. The goal: give campaign creators a chat-like interface (as natural as ChatGPT) that could:“Find 5 dance creators in Brazil with 100k+ followers. ”“Remove anyone with engagement below 0. 8. ”“Update my budget to $5,000. ”All via conversation.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: my budget to $5,000. ”All via conversation. Behind the scenes, the system had to build and refine creator lists, update campaign settings, and surface insights about the creators. Step 0: What an Agent Actually Is2025 was supposed to be the year of the “agent”. Not happening people. Behind the buzzwords lurks something pretty useful. An agent typically follows a pattern:Input: user text (messy, ambiguous, contextual). Interpretation: convert your unstructured request to structured instructions.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: unstructured request to structured instructions. Execution: do the thing (queries, API calls, updates) to achieve the user’s desire (within reason). Example:User: “Find Canadian food bloggers with 100k followers. ”Structured intent could be interpreted into something like this:{ “action”: “database”, “criteria”: { “country”: “Canada”, “minFollowers”: 100000, “niche”: “Food” }}Why structured outputs. They give you a contract.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: structured outputs. They give you a contract. Free-form text is unpredictable; JSON gives us the type safety, testability, and safe execution we expect from traditional APIs. More on that in a minute. Lesson 1: Don’t Build a Swiss-Army AgentMy first attempt at this project was a “do-everything” agent: one giant prompt, tons of context, vague rules. It was fragile and inconsistent. The fix was applying the Single Responsibility Principle: keep agents focused. One agent does one thing well.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: agents focused. One agent does one thing well. Here’s the pattern I’m using:Selector (Orchestrator): decides what to do next. Can summarize a conversation and extract intent. Database Agent: structured filters (followers, regions, niches) to find people. Search Agent: semantic style/vibe (“comedic creators”, “minimalist aesthetic”, “cats who eat pizza”). Refine Agent: adjust an existing list (“remove under 100k”). General Agent: analysis and summaries. “Who is most likely to go viral.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: and summaries. “Who is most likely to go viral. ”Update Agent: budget, targets, goals. “Update my budget to 1 Million Dollars” (twirls mustache)Launch Agent: finalization step to launch the campaign once they confirm they’re ready to gooooooo.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: once they confirm they’re ready to gooooooo. Selector Agent Exampleimport { createTracedOpenAI } from ‘@/lib/serverOpenai’;import { zodTextFormat } from ‘openai/helpers/zod’;import { z } from ‘zod’;type RouteAction = | ‘database’ | ‘search’ | ‘refine’ | ‘general’ | ‘update’ | ‘launch’ | ‘clarify’;type SelectorResponse = { action: RouteAction; reasoning: string; agentRequest: string;};export async function selectorAgent( userQuery: string): Promise<SelectorResponse> { const openai = createTracedOpenAI({ agentType: 'selector', userId: 'example-user', campaignId: 'example-campaign', }); const result = await openai.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: }); const result = await openai. responses. parse({ model: 'gpt-4o-mini', input: [ { role: 'system', content: 'Route to one of: database, search, refine, general, update, launch, clarify. ', }, { role: 'user', content: userQuery }, ], text: { format: zodTextFormat( z. object({ action: z. enum([ 'database', 'search', 'refine', 'general', 'update', 'launch', 'clarify', ]), reasoning: z.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: 'clarify', ]), reasoning: z. string(). describe('Why the request was routed here'), agentRequest: z. string(). describe('Concise request for the chosen agent'), }), 'agentResponse' ), }, }); if (. result. output_parsed) { throw new Error('Failed to parse AI response'); } return { action: result. output_parsed. action, reasoning: result. output_parsed. reasoning, agentRequest: result. output_parsed.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: reasoning, agentRequest: result. output_parsed. agentRequest, };}What’s happening here: Using OpenAI’s API, we are passing a user query to be interpreted and a schema to the OpenAI library so that we get a structured response. Now we can be confident the AI will return an object that matches what we expect. Pro tip: I use the “describe” property on the schema to help the model understand what each property will be used for. This appears to improve responses.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: be used for. This appears to improve responses. Lesson 2: Don’t Overfeed the ModelEarly on, I shoved full conversation histories and giant prompts into every request. It raised latency, costs, and errors. BTW — OpenAI is NOT free. Experiments can be costly but honestly, for a small project, $10 will be sufficient. Context is EVERYTHING.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: $10 will be sufficient. Context is EVERYTHING. In a conversation, if someone responds “yeah sure” — that phrase is meaningless unless you know that the previous phrase was “Are you willing to sacrifice yourself for the greater good of humanity. ”Agents need context to understand user intention but passing massive conversations each time a user hits “submit” will result in errors from OpenAI which has a limit on context.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: errors from OpenAI which has a limit on context. For example, you cannot pass a novella to OpenAI and expect it to handle that. The fix:Summarize the last 5 messages before routing. Keep agent prompts short and precise. Pass only what the next agent needs to perform the next task.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the next agent needs to perform the next task. Lesson 3: Orchestration > AutonomyAutonomous chains that take in an input and can call other agents at-will sounds really cool but when I experimented with this on a personal project, I had less visibility into why an agent called another agent or why they might loop infinitely and burn tokens at warp speed. For this reason, I chose to use orchestration:Selector chooses next agent. One specialized agent executes.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: next agent. One specialized agent executes. Aggregator/formatter finalizes the output for the user. Keep chains to 2–3 hops. Reliability degrades as steps increase. Here’s some math for you:Some studies show AI agents have ~70% success rate for common office tasks. With multiple agents, your chance of failure increases as you add agents. Let’s be very generous and consider our agent has a 90% success rate.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: and consider our agent has a 90% success rate. 2 agents: 90% of 90% = 81%3 agents: 90% of 90% of 90% = 72%4 agents: 90% of 90% of 90% of 90% = 66%Math. Lesson 4: You Can’t Improve What You Don’t MeasureIf you can’t see what your agents did and why, you can’t debug or improve them. I’ve used LangSmith and Helicone to trace calls and capture metadata. import OpenAI from ‘openai’;import { wrapOpenAI } from ‘langsmith/wrappers’;const baseOpenAI = new OpenAI({ apiKey: process. env.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: baseOpenAI = new OpenAI({ apiKey: process. env. OPENAI_API_KEY });// Attach traces to a LangSmith projectexport const tracedOpenAI = wrapOpenAI(baseOpenAI, { project_name: 'example-agent-project',});export function createTracedOpenAI(agentType: string) { return wrapOpenAI(baseOpenAI, { project_name: 'example-agent-project', tags: [agentType], metadata: { agent_type: agentType }, });}Now you can create a dashboard where you can see how agents are responding, the latency of the calls you’re making and token costs.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: of the calls you’re making and token costs. This is basic software development practices for observing failures but made for this new era of AI everywhere (whether you like it or not). Lesson 5: There Will Be TestsI was on the fence about writing tests honestly. Sometimes it feels like standard software development practices have just gone out the window in the age of AI. I’d argue that tests are even MORE important when using AI generated responses. Imagine this:You have an agent working great.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Imagine this:You have an agent working great. OpenAI updates their code which you have no visibility into. Maybe you just tweak a prompt. Things break spectacularly and you have no clue why or who to yell at. A small test suite can save you a lot of headache if you structure your agents correctly. I decided to use “live tests” that hit the API with representative queries and check on the structured output to see if it matches my expectations.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: output to see if it matches my expectations. This is yet another reason to use structure outputs, otherwise you may to have to use an LLM-as-judge approach to see if your output is “good enough”. Basically, passing the output from the test to another LLM to check the quality. To me, this seems brittle and error-prone (not to mention costly)import { selectorAgent } from ‘.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: to mention costly)import { selectorAgent } from ‘. /agents/selector’;describe('Selector Agent (routing)', () => { it('routes common queries correctly', async () => { const cases = [ { q: 'Find Canadian food bloggers with 100k followers', expected: 'database' }, { q: 'Add creators with tattoos', expected: 'search' }, { q: 'Remove anyone under 50k followers', expected: 'refine' }, { q: 'Update my budget to $10,000', expected: 'update' }, ]; for (const c of cases) { const res = await selectorAgent(c.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: c of cases) { const res = await selectorAgent(c. q); expect(res. action). toBe(c. expected); expect(res. agentRequest). toBeTruthy(); } }, 60000);});Yes, this costs tokens. It’s cheaper than shipping bugs and losing customers or the 2 strands of hair I have left on my shiny head. Lesson 6: Keep Agents Focused on Structured CriteriaNever let your model write raw database queries. Extract structured filters from text, then let your ORM/queries enforce reality.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: text, then let your ORM/queries enforce reality. This can be really powerful when you want to create a query from a user request. I follow this pattern:Do a query for possible values that our DB can accept. Agent uses this context and the user query to extract valid values to use in a database query. Enforce types using zod so we don’t use strings as numbers or vice-versa. import { z } from “zod”;import { zodTextFormat } from “openai/helpers/zod”;import { createOpenAI } from “.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: { createOpenAI } from “. /lib/openai”;// Define what fields we allow the model to returnconst searchSchema = z. object({ country: z. string(). optional(), niche: z. string(). optional(), minFollowers: z. number(). nullable(). optional(), maxFollowers: z. number(). nullable().

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: optional(), maxFollowers: z. number(). nullable(). optional(),});const MOCK = [ { handle: “foodie_ca”, followers: 120000, country: “Canada”, niche: “Food” }, { handle: “veganchef”, followers: 98000, country: “Canada”, niche: “Food” }, { handle: “travel_guru”, followers: 240000, country: “USA”, niche: “Travel” },];const userQuery = “Find food influencers in Canada with over 100k followers”;async function safeSearch(userQuery: string) { const openai = createOpenAI(); // Let the model parse search criteria — not SQL const parsed = await openai.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: criteria — not SQL const parsed = await openai. responses. parse({ model: “gpt-4o-mini”, input: `Extract structured search filters from this request: “${userQuery}”`, text: { format: zodTextFormat(searchSchema, “criteria”) }, }); const criteria = parsed. output_parsed; // Apply filters in your own code or ORM return MOCK. filter( (c) => (. criteria. country || c. country === criteria. country) && (. criteria. niche || c. niche === criteria. niche) && (. criteria. minFollowers || c.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: niche) && (. criteria. minFollowers || c. followers >= criteria. minFollowers) && (. criteria. maxFollowers || c. followers <= criteria. maxFollowers) );}safeSearch(userQuery). then(console. log);A Minimal End-to-End Exampleasync function runDemo() { const query = ‘Find Canadian food bloggers with 100k followers’; const route = await selectorAgent(query); if (route. action === 'database') { const results = await safeSearch(route. agentQuery); console.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: = await safeSearch(route. agentQuery); console. log('Creators:', results); } else { console. log('Unhandled action:', route. action); }}runDemo(). catch(console. error);There Are No RulesThere isn’t a right way to build agents but there are many wrong ways. I shared what is working for me in the real world. Not a tutorial. Not my 1 person “startup” with zero customers. I’ve built and shipped agents out in the wild with actual users.

metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Building AI Agents
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: shipped agents out in the wild with actual users. Here’s the thing: most of the tools in this space are a year or two old. The rules are still being written. In a few months, I’ll probably disagree with parts of this article. Maybe all of it. That’s fine. We’re all learning in public. The fun is in building, testing, and sharing what works. Want to go deeper down the rabbit hole. 👇Check out this project to learn RAG with AI and Typescript. Hands-on type shit for developers who want to build.

content: How You Save BigBax: A Guide to Unit Testing AI FeaturesRepeat after me: I love AI, it can do no wrong. You are writing tests right. Let’s pretend you’re working for one of those “AI” startups which basically is a wrapper for ChatGPT (I honestly don’t think this is such a bad thing but whatevs). This hypothetical startup helps users track calories by having them upload a list of what they ate and did for the day. We shall call this company BigBax️️️™️.

metadata.title: How You Save BigBax: A Guide to Unit Testing AI Features
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the day. We shall call this company BigBax️️️™️. Typical user input:“Yesterday I ate 10 donuts, a few bags of hot chips, a sweet pickle and binged Netflix. Oh, and I also threw my remote at the TV a few times during the big game. ”You create a function which takes a user input and then outputs the amount of calories they ate for the day. Your users start noticing nonsense output and complain. The engineering manager demands some tests to make sure this kind of mistake doesn’t happen.

metadata.title: How You Save BigBax: A Guide to Unit Testing AI Features
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: to make sure this kind of mistake doesn’t happen. This last slip-up cost BigBax️™️ ️2 users. That’s 10% of their total base. Unacceptable. “But OpenAI can return… anything. How can I ever write a test for this. ”“Figure it out bucko or that sweet 0. 5% equity won’t mean diddly-squat. ”In this article, you’ll learn:why mocks don’t work for LLMs,what kind of tests actually tell you when something breaks,how to write tests using structured outputs, schemas, and a little math-safety.

metadata.title: How You Save BigBax: A Guide to Unit Testing AI Features
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: outputs, schemas, and a little math-safety. Let’s protect your equity and save BigBax™️. The Feature: Parsing Calories and Exercise BurnImagine your app lets users type something like:“I ate a few old fashioned donuts today and sat in my rocking chair. I rocked vigorously. I imagine I burned around 3k calories overall”and it calculates the net calories for the day. That means your system needs to:Parse numbers like 3k to 3000. Distinguish between calories consumed and calories burned.

metadata.title: How You Save BigBax: A Guide to Unit Testing AI Features
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: between calories consumed and calories burned. Add or subtract them for the total. Seems straightforward… until you try to test it. What Most People Do (and Why It Sucks)Seriously, I’ve seen these kinds of tests in a codebase and I am genuinely curious why they exist. Here’s what most developers try first:// ❌ calorieAgent. test. tsjest. mock("@/lib/openai", () => ({ chat: jest. fn(() => ({ output: "You consumed 3000 and burned 750. Total: 2250. " }))}));import { calorieAgent } from ".

metadata.title: How You Save BigBax: A Guide to Unit Testing AI Features
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: 2250. " }))}));import { calorieAgent } from ". /calorieAgent";test("calculates total calories", async () => { const result = await calorieAgent("I ate 3k calories but burned 750"); expect(result). toBe("You consumed 3000 and burned 750. Total: 2250. ");});This passes. Every time. Forever. Because you’re not testing the real thing, you’re testing your mocked imagination of the model.

metadata.title: How You Save BigBax: A Guide to Unit Testing AI Features
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: testing your mocked imagination of the model. The day OpenAI changes its weights, or your teammate tweaks a prompt, or “3k” starts getting parsed as 3 instead of 3000…Your mock won’t catch it. You absolute fool. You’ll deploy confidently, and production will break quietly. Mocks give you a false sense of control in a non-deterministic system. BigBax™️ can’t afford this kind of oversight. Why Mocks Fail for LLMsLLMs are non-deterministic. You can’t rely on the same text twice.

metadata.title: How You Save BigBax: A Guide to Unit Testing AI Features
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: You can’t rely on the same text twice. Mocking assumes stability that doesn’t exist. They change over time. Model updates, temperature shifts, and prompt changes all alter output behavior. Mocks freeze drift. Your app evolves, your model evolves, but your mock stays stuck in time — hiding regressions instead of surfacing them. They don’t validate structure. You can’t test whether your code correctly parses or reacts to real responses if your mock is hard-coded text.

metadata.title: How You Save BigBax: A Guide to Unit Testing AI Features
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: to real responses if your mock is hard-coded text. So if mocks are out then what the hell do we do. The manager is getting ancy. The Fix: Test Structure, Not (just) WordsInstead of asserting on raw strings, test what the model returns, not (just) how it says it. The key is to:Force the model to return structured output (e. g. JSON). Validate that structure with a schema. Handle logic and math deterministically outside the model. Let’s rebuild our calorie tracker the right way.

metadata.title: How You Save BigBax: A Guide to Unit Testing AI Features
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Let’s rebuild our calorie tracker the right way. Step 1: The Agent (LLM Parser)// calorieAgent. tsimport OpenAI from "openai";import { z } from "zod";const client = new OpenAI({ apiKey: process. env. OPENAI_KEY });const CalorieSchema = z. object({ consumedCalories: z. array(z. number()). describe('Best guess on calories consumed'), burnedCalories: z. array(z. number()).

metadata.title: How You Save BigBax: A Guide to Unit Testing AI Features
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: burnedCalories: z. array(z. number()). describe('Best guess on calories burned via normal movement and exercise')});export async function calorieAgent(userInput: string) { const result = await client. responses. parse({ model: "gpt-4o-mini", input: ` Extract calorie data from the user's text. Return two arrays: - consumedCalories: numbers related to eating - burnedCalories: numbers related to workouts and being an adult human Interpret "k" as 1000 (e. g. , "3k" → 3000).

metadata.title: How You Save BigBax: A Guide to Unit Testing AI Features
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: human Interpret "k" as 1000 (e. g. , "3k" → 3000). If no calories mentioned, do your best to guess the calories consumed from their self-reporting. Return valid JSON only. `, text: { format: "json", schema: CalorieSchema }, }); return result. output_parsed;}Now the LLM doesn’t return free-form text — it returns predictable structure that our zod schema enforcesStep 2: The Utility FunctionKeep the math outside the model so you can test it deterministically. // calorieUtils.

metadata.title: How You Save BigBax: A Guide to Unit Testing AI Features
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: can test it deterministically. // calorieUtils. tsexport function calculateNetCalories(parsed: { consumedCalories: number[]; burnedCalories: number[];}) { const totalConsumed = parsed. consumedCalories. reduce((a, b) => a + b, 0); const totalBurned = parsed. burnedCalories. reduce((a, b) => a + b, 0); return totalConsumed - totalBurned;}Step 3: Add Useful TestsNow that your agent returns consistent structure, you can write meaningful tests. // calorieAgent. test. tsimport { calorieAgent } from ".

metadata.title: How You Save BigBax: A Guide to Unit Testing AI Features
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: test. tsimport { calorieAgent } from ". /calorieAgent";import { calculateNetCalories } from ". /calorieUtils";describe("Calorie Agent", () => { it("parses and calculates correctly", async () => { const parsed = await calorieAgent( "I ate 3k calories today but burned 500 running and 250 lifting" ); const total = calculateNetCalories(parsed); expect(parsed. consumedCalories). toContain(3000); expect(parsed. burnedCalories). toEqual(expect. arrayContaining([500, 250])); expect(total).

metadata.title: How You Save BigBax: A Guide to Unit Testing AI Features
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: arrayContaining([500, 250])); expect(total). toBe(2250); }, 30000); it("handles nonsense gracefully", async () => { const parsed = await calorieAgent("asdfghjkl qwertyuiop"); const total = calculateNetCalories(parsed); expect(parsed. consumedCalories). toHaveLength(0); expect(parsed. burnedCalories). toHaveLength(0); expect(total).

metadata.title: How You Save BigBax: A Guide to Unit Testing AI Features
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: burnedCalories). toHaveLength(0); expect(total). toBe(0); }, 30000);});Notice what we’re testing:✅ Structure (arrays exist and contain numbers)✅ Logic (our math function returns consistent totals)✅ Sanity (nonsense input produces empty arrays)No mocks. No false confidence. Just real validation. Step 4: Run Them WiselyThese tests hit the real API. That costs money. Don’t run them in your normal CI suite.

metadata.title: How You Save BigBax: A Guide to Unit Testing AI Features
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: money. Don’t run them in your normal CI suite. Instead:npm run test:aior filter by name:jest --testNamePattern="Calorie Agent"Run them after prompt updates, before deploys, or on a nightly schedule. Your manager has no clue why or how these work but he’s impressed. You’re now promoted to lead AI engineer at the company. You’re also the only developer on the team. We will count this as a win. You’re welcome. The Takeaways❌ Don’t mock LLM outputs — they’ll lie to you.

metadata.title: How You Save BigBax: A Guide to Unit Testing AI Features
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Don’t mock LLM outputs — they’ll lie to you. ✅ Force structured responses with schemas (Zod and/or JSON schema). ✅ Keep logic and math deterministic. ✅ Test behavior and structure, not phrasing. ✅ Run tests selectively to control cost. Mocks make you feel safe. Real AI tests make you informed. And the goal isn’t to prove your model’s perfect, it’s to know the exact moment it stops being predictable. Good luck BigBax.

content: Can We Stop Telling Developers This Stuff Already. Over the last 11 years, I’ve worked with hundreds of people to change their careers and land jobs in software. The success rate has been high, but the hardest part isn’t teaching JavaScript or React, it’s rewiring people’s brains to unlearn all the garbage advice they’ve picked up online. A lot of this advice is well-intentioned. A lot of it is just for clicks.

metadata.title: Can We Stop Telling Developers This Stuff Already?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: well-intentioned. A lot of it is just for clicks. Either way, it ends up hurting developers who don’t yet have enough experience to see through it. Here’s some of the worst career advice I’ve seen floating around the internet. 1. “Don’t chase titles”“It’s all about skills, not titles. ”Except… that’s not how the job market works. Titles matter no matter what you might feel about it. They dictate your current salary, your next salary, and how you’re perceived by recruiters.

metadata.title: Can We Stop Telling Developers This Stuff Already?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: salary, and how you’re perceived by recruiters. If your title says Email Developer but you’re doing full-stack work with AI tools, nobody’s going to read between the lines. They’ll just move on. You don’t need to be cutthroat, but you absolutely need to care about titles. Otherwise, you’re cutting your career trajectory short before it even starts. 2. “Don’t build CRUD apps”This one’s laughable. CRUD (create, read, update, delete) is the foundation of almost everything we do as developers.

metadata.title: Can We Stop Telling Developers This Stuff Already?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: of almost everything we do as developers. To say “don’t build CRUD apps” is basically saying “don’t be a software developer. ”Your backend API. CRUD. Your fancy chatbot pulling data from the internet. CRUD with extra layers. Even worse, the people dunking on CRUD projects are usually the ones who got hired by building… CRUD projects. It’s like people who went to college and then tell everyone else not to. Don’t fall for it.

metadata.title: Can We Stop Telling Developers This Stuff Already?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: then tell everyone else not to. Don’t fall for it. CRUD is where you start, and honestly, it’s where you’ll spend most of your career — just with more complexity piled on. 3. “Don’t join a bootcamp”I’ve heard this a lot. I even said it myself 😅 and now I run one. Colleges work. Self taught works. Bootcamps work. Tens of thousands of people land jobs through them every year. They’ve lasted because they deliver results, not because of marketing hype. Well… maybe a little because of marketing hype.

metadata.title: Can We Stop Telling Developers This Stuff Already?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Well… maybe a little because of marketing hype. What gives them a bad name. High-pressure sales calls. Unrealistic promises. Zero barrier to entry. I hate all of that. But the model itself: accelerated, structured learning with accountability does in fact work. I mean, do you really think your state school has some proprietary knowledge that a coding bootcamp would not also have. 4. “Just give up”Spend five minutes on Reddit and you’ll find this nugget of wisdom:“You’ll never make it.

metadata.title: Can We Stop Telling Developers This Stuff Already?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: find this nugget of wisdom:“You’ll never make it. The market’s saturated. AI replaced you. Just quit. ”Truly, big brained activity. This is cynicism disguised as realism. There are hundreds of thousands of open software jobs every year. Yes, people fail to break in. But telling others to stop before they even start. That’s lazy, mean and stupid. The people who believe this advice are the ones who gave up themselves. 5.

metadata.title: Can We Stop Telling Developers This Stuff Already?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: advice are the ones who gave up themselves. 5. “Javascript (or insert popular library) sux”React, JavaScript, Python, Node, SQL, Next. js are popular for a reason: companies hire for them. Skipping the mainstream stack to learn some obscure “secret weapon” framework isn’t clever, it’s career sabotage. The industry consolidates around a small number of tools. Learn the ones companies actually pay for.

metadata.title: Can We Stop Telling Developers This Stuff Already?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: tools. Learn the ones companies actually pay for. Maybe do some market research and count the number of listings in your area by particular technology instead of letting social media dictate your decisions. There are only two types of languages and frameworks: the ones no one has heard of, and the ones everyone hates. Don’t overthink it. 6. “DSA doesn’t matter”“Nobody uses binary search trees at work. ”I used to believe this too. I mean, it’s kind of true — but interviews are a different game.

metadata.title: Can We Stop Telling Developers This Stuff Already?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: of true — but interviews are a different game. If you don’t know the basics of data structures, Big-O, or system design, you’re instantly disqualified from a big chunk of jobs. It’s not about grinding 500 LeetCode problems but you do need to be literate enough to survive the process. Ignore it completely, and you’re rate-limiting your career. Bad advice travels fastThe truth is so much more boring than the hot takes. “Don’t chase titles. ”“Don’t build CRUD apps. ”“Don’t join bootcamps.

metadata.title: Can We Stop Telling Developers This Stuff Already?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: ”“Don’t build CRUD apps. ”“Don’t join bootcamps. ”“Whiteboard interviews are dumb, just skip them. ”It feels contrarian. It feels bold. But it’s misleading without context. Here’s some meta-advice: take everything (including mine) with a grain of salt. My perspective comes from working with hundreds of career changers, but it’s still a small sample. What matters is figuring out what applies to you — and leaving the rest behind.

metadata.title: Can We Stop Telling Developers This Stuff Already?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: what applies to you — and leaving the rest behind. If you’re serious about becoming a software developer — especially if you’re changing careers — I run a program called Parsity that’s built for people like you. Practical skills, modern stack with AI (not hype) and super small by design. Check it out if you want structure and accountability on your journey.

metadata.title: Can We Stop Telling Developers This Stuff Already?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: How to Negotiate Your Salary as a Software Developer(and Stop Leaving Money on the Table)Most developers are terrible negotiators. I know, because for years I was one of them. For my first 3 jobs, I had no clue about salary negotiations. No one ever taught me what I’m going to share with you. Over the years, I’ve personally negotiated around $80–90K more in compensation using this exact method. Here’s a snapshot of my salary trajectory:1st job — $60K. (OMG my first role. I should be grateful.

metadata.title: How to Negotiate Your Salary as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: — $60K. (OMG my first role. I should be grateful. )2nd job — $120K. (OMG — this is more money than anyone I know makes)3rd job — $120K. (Eh, ok. )3rd job (again) — $150K (I had a competing offer and they matched. Wait — so you had that extra money the whole time. )4th job — $165K (I asked for $180K and they went from $150K to $165K with a $20K sign on)Current role — $200K (Negotiated from $180K to their highest band)I did not include other, non-monetary things.

metadata.title: How to Negotiate Your Salary as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: band)I did not include other, non-monetary things. Those amounts were my base salary at each role NOT including stocks/bonuses etc. Today, I’m going to walk you through how to negotiate your salary as a software developer without sounding greedy, awkward, or ungrateful. Because if you’ve ever been so thrilled to land an offer that you just blurt out “yes”… you’re not alone. But it’s costing you tens of thousands of dollars.

metadata.title: How to Negotiate Your Salary as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: But it’s costing you tens of thousands of dollars. Why Most Developers Fail to NegotiateUnfortunately, most people never learn the rules of the game. Scarcity mindset. You believe there aren’t enough jobs out there, so you’re lucky to even get one. Fear of rejection. You think asking for more will make them pull the offer. Over-researching. You waste hours on Glassdoor trying to find a “fair” number instead of just asking. Needing a reason.

metadata.title: How to Negotiate Your Salary as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: number instead of just asking. Needing a reason. You convince yourself you can’t ask without data or a justification. All of this leads to the same outcome: you take whatever number they give you and hope for the best. The problem. That’s not how the game works. The Good NewsNegotiation isn’t some dark art. You can learn it and it works for juniors, seniors, bootcamp grads, everyone. You don’t need multiple offers. You don’t need 10 years of experience. You just need to ask, in the right way.

metadata.title: How to Negotiate Your Salary as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: You just need to ask, in the right way. Step 1: Ditch the Research Rabbit HoleStop obsessing over salary websites. The company already knows the market rate. If they’ve made you an offer, it’s rarely their ceiling. Even if the number seems big compared to what you’ve made before, assume there’s still room. There usually is. Step 2: Use This Simple ScriptHere’s the exact script I use:“I’m really grateful for the opportunity and excited about the role.

metadata.title: How to Negotiate Your Salary as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: for the opportunity and excited about the role. I was hoping to come closer to this range [x] however. I’m happy to chat more and eager to join the team. Please let me know your thoughts. ”That’s it. Don’t over-explain. Don’t justify. Just say it, pause, and wait. If you want a number: 10–15% above what they offered is usually fair. It signals confidence, not greed. Step 3: Avoid the Rookie MistakeThe only way to blow an offer is to ask for something absurd (like double) or act entitled.

metadata.title: How to Negotiate Your Salary as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: something absurd (like double) or act entitled. Otherwise, the worst you’ll hear is “we can’t do that. ”And even then, you’ve shown that you know your worth which often comes back around during the first raise cycle. Step 4: Negotiate Beyond SalaryIf they can’t move on cash, shift to other levers:Sign-on bonus (companies will often use these to appease you.

metadata.title: How to Negotiate Your Salary as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: (companies will often use these to appease you. It’s one-time money and you get taxed ~40%)Stocks or profit sharingRemote or hybrid flexibilityExtra PTO or training budgetAt one job, I negotiated to work from home 2. 5 days a week and only be in the office from 10 a. m. — 2 p. m. I had the same workload and expectations, just more freedom to get my kids from school and avoid a super long commute. That was worth it to me.

metadata.title: How to Negotiate Your Salary as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: a super long commute. That was worth it to me. Step 5: Remember Who Holds the LeverageIf you’ve gotten an offer, they’ve already decided: you’re their person. They’ve spent weeks interviewing, screening, and debating. Starting that process over is expensive. And here’s what most developers forget you’re not taking money from them personally. They’re spending the company’s budget, not their own paycheck. So ask.

metadata.title: How to Negotiate Your Salary as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: company’s budget, not their own paycheck. So ask. Step 6: Think Long-TermIf they truly can’t budge, say this:“Would it be possible to revisit compensation after six months based on performance. ”That one line signals maturity, and often opens the door for future raises. This Isn’t Theory — It’s ProvenI’ve helped multiple Parsity students with negotiations. Most earn an average of $10K more just by asking. One dude, Eric, went from $80K to $93K.

metadata.title: How to Negotiate Your Salary as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: by asking. One dude, Eric, went from $80K to $93K. He hadn’t been employed for 6 months so this was a particularly big ask. Honestly… most students never follow my advice. They are too afraid to ask. Meanwhile, as a manager, I personally hired for the same job at the same time with a $15K gap between the people. One negotiated and the other didn’t. Fair. Of course not. Do you honestly think companies are scrambling to pay you more. Bless your heart.

metadata.title: How to Negotiate Your Salary as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: are scrambling to pay you more. Bless your heart. You and I are playing a game and it’s important to know the rules. Your TemplateHere’s the exact message you can send after getting an offer:Hi [Manager’s Name],I’m really grateful for the offer and genuinely excited about the opportunity to join [your evil company]. I was hoping to come in a little closer to [some dollar amount around 10–15% more], based on my experience and the scope of the role.

metadata.title: How to Negotiate Your Salary as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: based on my experience and the scope of the role. I’m very interested and looking forward to next steps. Best,Your NameThat’s it. Simple, confident, human. Final ThoughtsWhether you’re making $60K or $160K, the game is the same and it’s already being played. If you choose not to play, fine. But understand what that means:You’re leaving money on the table that could’ve been yours. So use the script. Ask for what you want. And if you need a pep talk before you hit “send,” I’ve got you.

metadata.title: How to Negotiate Your Salary as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: a pep talk before you hit “send,” I’ve got you. Until then…Know the rules. Use the template. And YOLO. At Parsity we help career changers learn enough to be hireable and then bully them into negotiating. Small cohorts, 1 on 1 mentorship at an accredited school. Run by developers for developers. Already a fullstack developer and want to level up with AI in a practical way. Check this out.

metadata.title: How to Negotiate Your Salary as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney
